Game of life
  • X

    Game of Life - Rules

    For a space that is populated:

    Each cell with one or no neighbors dies, as if by soltitude

    Each cell with four or more neighbors dies, as if by overpopulation.

    Each cell with two or three neighbors survives.

    For a space that is empty or unpopulated:

    Each cell with three neighbors becomes populated.

History

Learn about John Horton Conway and his Game of Life

John Horton Conway was a British mathematician known for his work in several branches of mathematics, including group theory, cryptography, geometry, and number theory. He is best known for inventing the surreal numbers and the Game of Life. Conway passed away on April 11, 2020, due to COVID-19.

Read More →

The Game of Life, created by British mathematician John Conway in 1970, is a cellular automaton consisting of a two-dimensional grid with cells that can be "alive" or "dead". These cells evolve according to specific rules and can form various patterns over time. One interacts with the Game of Life by creating an initial configuration and observing how it evolves.
